awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Growth and Remodeling of the Uterine Cervix During Pregnancy
awd_abstract_narration:
This NSF Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award will characterize the biomechanical mechanisms that cause preterm birth (PTB) and will train the next generation of female engineers with educational activities geared towards Women's Health. Despite advances in prenatal care, the rate of PTB (birth before 37 weeks of gestation) in the United States remains high. This fact underscores how little is known about the causes of PTB, which is a leading cause of death in children under five. Researchers do know that the cervix, a cylindrical organ located at the base of the uterus, is a critical mechanical barrier to maintain the baby to full term. Then, at time of delivery the cervix is instructed by hormonal cues to remodel, soften, and dilate to become a safe passage for the baby. If this cervical tissue remodeling timing is off, PTB can occur due to premature cervical dilation. The understanding of this cervical remodeling process is limited because there are no engineering tools to characterize normal and abnormal cervical softening. To address this need, this study will measure the mechanical and biochemical property changes of the cervix under various hormonal cues and derive a set of equations that can predict the mechanical function of the cervix during pregnancy. This study will bring an improved understanding to the underlying causes of PTB related to cervical dysfunction, and will be an essential step toward the development of rational therapies to prevent PTB.

This CAREER study will derive a constitutive material modeling framework for the growth and remodeling of the cervix during pregnancy. The main goal is to determine the driving factors that cause premature cervical remodeling and the mechanical dysfunction of the cervix. The modeling framework will be based on the evidence that levels of estrogen and progesterone play a key role in regulating cervical tissue composition during pregnancy. Cervical tissue will be modeled as a hydrated fiber composite porous material where the interstitial pore space allows for the growth and removal of solid mass. The associated material parameters will evolve as a function of hormone-mediated extracelluar matrix compositional state variables. Model functions will be based on mechanical and collagen characterization of gestation-timed cervical tissue samples taken from established mouse models of hormone-mediated normal, preterm, and disrupted cervical remodeling. These equations will be validated by assessing their predictive capability of the material response to loading and hormonally-driven tissue changes.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
The uterine cervix undergoes one of the most dramatic tissue remodeling events in the human body. In pregnancy, the cervix has a dual mechanical role. First, the cervix must remain closed to be a mechanical barrier for the growing fetus. At term, the cervix must be soft enough to dilate for safe delivery. After delivery, the tissue must have enough material resilience to recoil back to shape to prevent maternal hemorrhage and repair for subsequent pregnancies. This engineering project established experimental protocols and material models to measure and quantify tissue biomechanical properties of the murine cervix throughout the dramatic tissue remodeling events in pregnancy. The mechanical testing protocols and material models can be widely applied to hydrated collagenous tissues experiencing rapid remodeling events.  Additionally, this project trained the next generation of engineers on reproductive biomechanics, a field supporting innovation in women’s health, through lab experiences and new coursework from the high school to the doctoral level.

 

This project discovered the cervix maintains its mechanical functionality through pregnancy while it simultaneously orchestrates a well-timed structural remodeling to prepare for parturition. Mechanical tests were conducted on nonpregnant and pregnant tissue using wild-type mice and mouse models of infection mediated preterm birth, hormone withdrawal mediated preterm birth, and disrupted collagen and elastic fibers (small-leucine rich proteoglycan genetic knock-out animals). Cyclic ramp-hold mechanical tests were developed to understand tissue stiffness, the capacity of the mouse cervix to recover after small and large deformations, and the tissue’s ability to dissipate loads. In nonpregnancy and early pregnancy, the densely crosslinked collagen network of the cervix results in a stiff tissue. The cervix initiates a gradual softening throughout pregnancy whereby compliance, ability to dissipate load (i.e., viscoelasticity), and resilience to breaking are increased at precisely timed hormone-mediated stages. At the end of pregnancy, compliance and viscoelasticity are at a maximal high, giving the tissue the ability to undergo large stretch without breaking. Moreover, premature cervical remodeling induced by infection is characterized by distinct mechanical properties that are similar but not identical to mechanical properties changes induced by hormonal shifts. Infection-mediated remodeling induces embrittlement of the tissue, where tissue cannot undergo cyclic loading to large stretch levels without breaking. In contrast, hormone-mediated remodeling during pregnancy is characterized by the drastic increase in tissue compliance and viscoelasticity in late-stage remodeling. Taken together, hormone-mediated remodeling in the mouse cervix is a robust mechanism to create a ductile and compliant soft tissue that can accommodate large amounts of stretch.

 


Last Modified: 01/03/2022
Modified by: Kristin M Myers
